name: 中世紀晚期至十八世紀祭壇畫：主題、風格與功能
description: Concerning its form and function, the altarpiece was always closely connected with the focal point of every church, the altar. As a consequence, it played a key role in Christian liturgy and devotion since its emergence in the High Middle Ages. The course will provide an overview of the cultural background and the multifarious functions of the altarpiece from the earliest examples to late manifestations in Romanticism. Case studies will be used to follow formal development and characteristics and the different aspects of use. A special focus will be laid on the periods of transition and radical change, such as the Reformation and Counter-Reformation as well as the Enlightenment.
goals: To increase students’ knowledge of the stylistic and iconographic development of this major species of art work.
To increase students’ knowledge of the historical and cultural background of the art works and to discuss the changes of their function through the ages.
To train students’ ability of analytical description and comparative analysis of form using the correct terminology.
To improve students’ capacity of esthetic judgment.
To instruct students how to read and interpret primary sources and evaluate them with regard to the relevant art works.
To promote students’ competencies to collect and interpret related literature and to encourage them to maintain a critical distance towards scientific opinions.
syllabus:
1.  Introduction into the topic—Functions of the altar in Christian liturgy. The emergence of the altarpiece in the Middle Ages: first appearances and early examples. Altarpieces and relics, altarpieces and tombs. 12th/13th centuries: _Pala d’Oro_, high altar retable, 1105 with later additions, Venice, S Marco. Discussion of content of form of term papers.
2.  Early examples in Italy—13th century: Bonaventura Berlinghieri, _St Francis_, 1235, Pescia, S Francesco; _St Catherine_, 1250s, Pisa, Museo Nazionale S Matteo; Coppo di Marcovaldo, _Madonna del Bordone_, 1261, Siena, S. Maria dei Servi. Distribution of the topics for term papers.
3.  Italian Altarpieces around 1300—Cimabue, Duccio, Giotto and contemporaries: Cimabue, _[Santa Trinita Madonna](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T002082?q=Altarpiece&search=quick&pos=1&_start=1#F015410)_ (1280–85), Florence, Uffizi; Duccio, _[Rucellai Madonna](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/img/grove/art/F015421)_, (1285, Florence, Uffizi; Giotto, _[Ognissanti Madonna](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/img/grove/art/F015432)_ (_c._ 1310), Florence, Uffizi; Duccio, _Maestà_, for the Cathedral of Siena (1308–11), Siena, Opera del Duomo; Giotto, _Stefaneschi_ altarpiece (_c._ 1320), Rome, Pinacoteca Vaticana.
4.  Early Netherlandish painting—The winged altarpiece (Germ.: _Flügelaltar_): Hubert and Jan van Eyck, _Ghent_ altarpiece (1423–32), Ghent, St Bavo; Rogier van der Weyden, [_Descent From the Cross_](http://www.visual-arts-cork.com/famous-paintings/descent-from-the-cross-weyden.htm) (1435–40), Madrid, Prado; _Last Judgment_ polyptych (1443–51), Beaune, Hôtel-Dieu; Hugo van der Goes, _[Portinari altarpiece](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/img/grove/art/F014915)_ (_c._ 1473–78), Florence, Uffizi; Hans Memling, _Last Judgment_ polyptych (1443–51), Gdansk, National Museum.
5.  German painting of the 15th century: [Stefan Lochner](http://www.visual-arts-cork.com/old-masters/stefan-lochner.htm), _Three Kings Altarpiece_ (_c._ 1440), Cologne, Cathedral. Early winged altarpieces and their role in liturgy.
6.  German painted winged altarpieces I—The time of Albrecht Dürer: _Paumgartner Altarpiece_ (post 1503), Munich, Alte Pinakothek; _Feast of Rose Garlands_ (1506), Prague, National Gallery; _Heller_ altarpiece (_Assumption of the Virgin_) (1509); _Landauer_ altarpiece (_Adoration of the Trinity_) (1505–16), Kunsthistorisches Museum Vienna.
7.  German painted winged altarpieces II: Matthias Grünewald, _Isenheim_ altarpiece (1506–15), Colmar, Musée d’Unterlinden.
8.  Painted and sculpted polyptychs: [Michael Pacher](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T064439), [_St Wolfgang_ altarpiece](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T002082?q=Altarpiece&search=quick&pos=1&_start=1#F015458), (1471–81), St Wolfgangsee, St Wolfgang; Veit Stoss, _Kraków_ altarpiece, (1477–89), Kraków, St Mary; Michel Erhart, _Virgin and Child with Saints_ (_c._ 1493–94), Blaubeuren, Benedictine Convent Church;
9.  Carved limewood altarpieces: Tilman Riemenschneider, _Last Supper/__Holy Blood_ altarpiece (1499–1504), St Jakob Church, Rothenburg o.T.; _St Mary_ altarpiece (_Assumption_) (1505–10), Creglingen, Herrgottskirche.
10.  Italian Early Renaissance/Tuscany: Piero della Francesca, _Madonna della Misericordia_ (1445–1462);
11.  Italian Early Renaissance/Venice, Veneto: Donatello, _Virgin and Child with Saints_ (1443–50), Padua, Basilica del Santo; Andrea Mantegna, _S Zeno_ altarpiece (1457–60), Verona, S Zeno; Giovanni Bellini, _S Zaccaria_ altarpiece (1505), Venice, S Zaccaria.
12.  Italian High Renaissance/Tuscany: Raphael, _Entombment_ (1507), Rome, Galleria Borghese; S Cecilia (1513), Bologna, Pinacoteca; [_Sistine Madonna_](http://www.visual-arts-cork.com/famous-paintings/sistine-madonna.htm) (1515), Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister, Dresden.
13.  Italian High Renaissance/Venice, Veneto: Giorgione, Castelfranco altarpiece (_c._ 1504), Castelfranco Vto, S Liberale; Titian, [_Assumption of the Virgin_](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/img/grove/art/F015494) (1516–18), Venice, S Maria Gloriosa dei Frari; [_Pesaro Madonna_](http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T085242?q=Titian&search=quick&pos=1&_start=1#F015495) (1519–26), Venice, S Maria Gloriosa dei Frari; _Death of_ _St Peter Martyr_ for SS Giovanni e Paolo (1526–30; destr. 1867); Paolo Veronese.
14.  The altarpiece between Reformation and Counter-Reformation—Altars without altarpieces, churches without altars. Reform tendencies after the Council of Trent (1545–63).
15.  Spain between Late Renaissance and Baroque: El Greco, _The Santo Domingo el Antiguo_ altarpieces (1577–79); _Funeral of Count Orgaz_ (1586–88), S Tomé, Toledo.
16.  Roman Baroque: Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio and the Carracci; Guido Reni.
17.  Northern Baroque: Peter Paul Rubens, _Raising of the Cross_ for the church of St Walburga (1610–11), and _Descent from the Cross_ (1612–14), Antwerp Cathedral.
18.  Enlighenment and Romanticism: Caspar David Friedrich, _Cross in the Mountains_ (Tetschen Altarpiece), 1807–08, Dresden, Gemäldegalerie Neue Meister. The altar and altarpiece in modern times. Final discussion.

          Additional activities: field trip to Luce Chapel, Tunghai University; Holy Cross Church, Ching-Lao, Hou-Bi (Tainan).
